courses.name: Introductory Statistical Reasoning
courses.description: Statistical concepts for critically evaluation quantitative information.  Descriptive statistics, probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression.  Students may not receive credit if they have received or are concurrently receiving credit for a higher numbered course offered by the Statistics Department.  Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in MATH 1050 or MATH 1100 or  MATH 1120 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1180 or exemption from College Algebra by examination

courses.name: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Collection, presentation of data; averages; dispersion; introduction to statistical inference, correlation and regression. Students may not receive credit if they have received or are concurrently receiving credit for another course offered by the Statistics Department. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: grade in C - or higher in MATH 1100 or  MATH 1120 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1180 or exemption from college algebra by examination

courses.name: Elementary Statistics - Honors
courses.description: Collection, presentation of data; averages; dispersion; introduction to statistical inference, correlation and regression. Students may not receive credit if they have received or are concurrently receiving credit for another course offered by the Statistics Department.  Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C-or higher in MATH 1100 or MATH 1120 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1180 or exemption from college algebra by examination. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Elementary Statistics for Life Sciences
courses.description: Designed for students studying agriculture and other life sciences. Descriptive statistics, probability, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation and regression.  Students may not receive credit if they have received or are concurrently receiving credit for another course offered by the Statistics Department. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: grade in C- or higher in MATH 1050 or MATH 1100 or MATH 1120 or MATH 1160 or MATH 1180 or exemption from college algebra by examination

courses.name: Introductory Statistical Methods
courses.description: Designed to upgrade the curriculum of STAT 1200 or STAT 1300 or STAT 1400 to the level of STAT 2500. Students may not receive credit for STAT 2200 if they have completed a course from the Department of Statistics numbered 2500 or higher.  Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: grade in C- or higher in STAT 1200 or STAT 1300 or STAT 1400

courses.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics I
courses.description: Designed primarily for students in College of Business. Descriptive statistics, probability, random variables, sampling distributions, estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis tests. Math Reasoning Proficiency course.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C- or better in MATH 1300 or  MATH 1400 or MATH 1500

courses.name: Statistical Methods in Natural Resources
courses.description: Statistical methods, with emphasis on applications to natural resources and including computer exercises. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course.
courses.prerequisites: a college-level computing course and a grade in the C range or better in MATH 1100, MATH 1120, MATH 1160, or MATH 1180

courses.name: Introduction to Probability and Statistics II
courses.description: Continuation of STAT 2500. Coverage of additional topics including: Regression; model building; ANOVA; nonparametic methods; use of a statistical computer package.
courses.prerequisites: grade in the C - or higher in  STAT 2200 or STAT 2500 or STAT 2530, or  STAT 4710  or concurrent enrollment in STAT 2200

courses.name: Topics in Statistics-Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Repeatable with departmental consent.
courses.prerequisites: Consent of instructor required

courses.name: Connecting Statistics to Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: Primarily for middle and secondary mathematics education majors.  Uses standards-based curricular materials to demonstrate connections between college-level statistics and content taught in middle and secondary schools.  No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 1200 or STAT 1300 or STAT 1400 or STAT 2500 or STAT 4710 or ESC_PS 4170 or MATH 2320

courses.name: Problems in Statistics for Undergraduates
courses.description: Independent investigations. Reports on approved topics.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Software and Data Analysis
courses.description: Programming with major statistical packages emphasizing data management techniques and statistical analysis for regression, analysis of variance, categorical data, descriptive statistics, non-parametric analyses, and other selected topics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Applied Categorical Data Analysis
courses.description: The study of statistical models and methods used in analyzing categorical data.  The use of computing is emphasized and calculus is not required.  No credit for students who have previously completed STAT 4830.  No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Applied Nonparametric Methods
courses.description: Statistical methods when the functional form of the population is unknown. Applications emphasized. Comparisons with parametric procedures. Goodness of-fit, chi-square, comparison of several populations, measures of correlation.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Sampling Techniques
courses.description: Theory of probability sampling designs. Unrestricted random sampling. Stratified sampling. Cluster sampling. Multistage or subsampling. Ratio estimates. Regression estimates. Double sampling.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Biostatistics and Clinical Trials
courses.description: (cross-leveled with STAT 7410). Study of statistical techniques for the design and analysis of clinical trials, laboratory studies and epidemiology. Topics include randomization, power and sample size calculation, sequential monitoring, carcinogenicity bioassay and case-cohort designs.
courses.prerequisites: any of the following: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710, STAT 7710, STAT 4760, STAT 7760, or instructor's consent.

courses.name: Applied Survival Analysis
courses.description: Parametric models; Kaplan-Meier estimator; nonparametric estimation of survival and cumulative hazard functions; log-rank test; Cox model; Stratified Cox model; additive hazards model partial likelihood; regression diagnostics; multivariate survival data.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis
courses.description: Repeated measurements; event history studies; linear and nonlinear mixed effects models; growth models; marginal mean and rate models; pattern-mixture models; selection models; non-informative and informative drop-out; joint analysis of  longitudinal and survival data.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Applied Statistical Methods for Bioinformatics
courses.description: Random variables; Point estimation; Multiple t-test; Likelihood principle; Analysis of variance; Probabilistic methods for sequence modeling; Gene expression analysis; Protein structure prediction; Genome analysis; Hierarchical clustering and Gene classification.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Applied Statistical Models I
courses.description: Introduction to applied linear models including regression (simple and multiple, subset selection, estimation and testing) and analysis of variance (fixed and random effects, multifactor models, contrasts, multiple testing).  No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Analysis of Variance
courses.description: Study of analysis of variance and related modeling techniques for cases with fixed, random, and mixed effects. Exposure to designs other than completely randomized designs including factorial arrangements, repeated measures, nested, and unequal sample size designs.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 7070 or STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Experimental Design
courses.description: Examination and analysis of modern statistical techniques applicable to experimentation in social, physical or biological sciences.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 4510 or STAT 7510 or STAT 4530 or STAT 7530

courses.name: Applied Multivariate Data Analysis
courses.description: Testing mean vectors; Discriminant analysis; Principal components; Factor analysis; Cluster analysis; Structural equation modeling; Graphics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070 STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent. No credit towards a graduate degree in statistics

courses.name: Introduction to Statistical Methods for Customized Pricing
courses.description: (cross-leveled with STAT 7580). Introduction to basic concepts of and statistical methods used in customized pricing.  Focuses on applying statistical methods to real customized pricing problems.  Students will gain an understanding of customized pricing and some hands on experience with SAS Enterprise Miner.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 4510 or STAT 7510 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Spatial Statistics
courses.description: Introduction to spatial random processes, spatial point patterns, kriging, simultaneous and conditional autoregression, and spatial data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4510 or instructor's consent
courses.recommendation: basic knowledge of calculus and matrices

courses.name: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
courses.description: Bayes formulas, choices of prior, empirical Bayesian methods, hierarchal Bayesian methods, statistical computation, Bayesian estimation, model selection, predictive analysis, applications, Bayesian software.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 4510 or STAT 7510

courses.name: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
courses.description: (same as MATH 4315). Introduction to theory of probability and statistics using concepts and methods of calculus.  No credit for MATH 4315.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300

courses.name: Introduction to Probability Theory
courses.description: (same as MATH 4320). Probability spaces; random variables and their distributions; repeated trials; probability limit theorems.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300

courses.name: Statistical Inference
courses.description: (same as MATH 4520). Sampling; point estimation; sampling distribution; tests of hypotheses; regression and linear hypotheses.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4750 or STAT 7750

courses.name: Nonparametric Methods
courses.description: A first course in Non-parametric statistical methods based on ranks. Both theory and application are emphasized. Two-sample problems. K-sample problems. Tests for independence. Contingency tables. Goodness-of-fit tests.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Categorical Data Analysis
courses.description: Discrete distributions, frequency data, multinomial data, chi-square and likelihood ratio tests, logistic regression, log linear models, rates, relative risks, random effects, case studies.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
courses.description: Study of random processes selected from: Markov chains, birth and death processes, random walks, Poisson processes, renewal theory, Brownian motion, Gaussian processes, white noise, spectral analysis, applications such as queuing theory, sequential tests.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4750 or STAT 7750

courses.name: Time Series Analysis
courses.description: A study of univariate and multivariate time series models and techniques for their analyses. Emphasis is on methodology rather than theory. Examples are drawn from a variety of areas including business, economics and soil science.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Senior Seminar
courses.description: A capstone course required of and open only to senior statistics majors. Students will participate in statistical consulting, attend colloquia, and review articles in professional journals. Writing of reports will be emphasized.
courses.prerequisites: senior statistics major and 12 completed hours of statistics courses or instructor's consent

courses.name: Junior/Senior Seminar - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A capstone course required of and open only to junior or senior statistics majors. Students will participate in statistical consulting, attend colloquia, and review articles in professional journals. Writing of reports will be emphasized.
courses.prerequisites: Statistics major with Junior or Senior class standing  or instructor's consent
courses.recommendation: 12 completed hours of statistics courses with grade of C or better; STAT 4110

courses.name: Departmental Honors in Statistics
courses.description: Special work for Honors candidates in statistics. May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: None Listed

courses.name: Topics in Statistics-Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. Repeatable with departmental consent.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Methods in the Health Sciences
courses.description: Basic inference methods, both parametric and non-parametric, appropriate for answering questions arising in health sciences research. Computer exercises involving data from real experiments from health science area.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 or MATH 1120 and instructor's consent

courses.name: Connecting Statistics to Middle and Secondary Schools
courses.description: Primarily for middle and secondary mathematics education majors.  Uses standards-based curricular materials to demonstrate connections between college-level statistics and content taught in middle and secondary schools.  No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: an introductory course in statistics or MATH 2320 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Methods for Research
courses.description: Designed for graduate students who have no previous training in statistics. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, regression, and ANOVA. No credit toward a degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: either MATH 1100 or MATH 1120

courses.name: Problems in Statistics for Non-majors
courses.description: Approved reading and study, independent investigations, and reports on approved topics.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Software and Data Analysis
courses.description: Programming with major statistical packages emphasizing data management techniques and statistical analysis for regression, analysis of variance, categorical data, descriptive statistics, non-parametric analyses, and other selected topics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Categorical Data Analysis
courses.description: The study of statistical models and methods used in analyzing categorical data.  The use of computing is emphasized and calculus is not required.  No credit for students who have previously completed STAT 4830.  No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Nonparametric Methods
courses.description: Statistical methods when the functional form of the population is unknown. Applications emphasized. Comparisons with parametric procedures. Goodness of-fit, chi-square, comparison of several populations, measures of correlation.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Sampling Techniques
courses.description: Theory of probability sampling designs. Unrestricted random sampling. Stratified sampling. Cluster sampling. Multistage or subsampling. Ratio estimates. Regression estimates. Double sampling.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Biostatistics and Clinical Trials
courses.description: (cross-leveled with STAT 4410). Study of statistical techniques for the design and analysis of clinical trials, laboratory studies and epidemiology. Topics include randomization, power and sample size calculation, sequential monitoring, carcinogenicty bioassay and case-cohort designs.
courses.prerequisites: any of the following: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710, STAT 7710, STAT 4760, STAT 7760, or instructor's consent.

courses.name: Applied Survival Analysis
courses.description: Parametric models; Kaplan-Meier estimator; nonparametric estimation of survival and cumulative hazard functions;  log-rank test; Cox model; Stratified Cox model; additive hazards model partial likelihood; regression diagnostics;  multivariate survival data.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis
courses.description: Repeated measurements; event history studies; linear and nonlinear mixed effects models; growth models; marginal mean and rate models; pattern-mixture models; selection models;  non-informative and informative drop-out; joint analysis of longitudinal and survival data.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Statistical Methods for Bioinformatics
courses.description: Random variables; Point estimation; Multiple t-test; Likelihood principle; Analysis of variance; Probabilistic methods for sequence modeling; Gene expression analysis; Protein structure prediction; Genome analysis; Hierarchical clustering and Gene classification.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Statistical Models I
courses.description: Introduction to applied linear models including regression (simple and multiple, subset selection, estimation and testing) and analysis of variance (fixed and random effects, multifactor models, contrasts, multiple testing). No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Analysis of Variance
courses.description: Study of analysis of variance and related modeling techniques for cases with fixed, random, and mixed effects. Exposure to designs other than completely randomized designs including factorial arrangements, repeated measures, nested, and unequal sample size designs.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Experimental Design
courses.description: Examination and analysis of modern statistical techniques applicable to experimentation in social, physical or biological sciences.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 4510 or STAT 7510 or STAT 4530 or STAT 7530 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Multivariate Data Analysis
courses.description: Testing mean vectors; discriminant analysis; principal components; factor analysis; cluster analysis; structural equation modeling; graphics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500, STAT 7070, STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760.  No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics

courses.name: Introduction to Statistical Methods for Customized Pricing
courses.description: (cross-leveled with STAT 4580). Introduction to basic concepts of and statistical methods used in customized pricing.  Focuses on applying statistical methods to real customized pricing problems.  Students will gain an understanding of customized pricing and some hands on experience with SAS Enterprise minor.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 4510 or STAT 7510 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Spatial Statistics
courses.description: Introduction to spatial random processes, spatial point patterns, kriging, simultaneous and conditional autoregression, and spatial data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4510 or STAT 7510 or instructor's consent
courses.recommendation: Basic knowledge of calculus and matrices

courses.name: Introduction to Bayesian Data Analysis
courses.description: Bayes formulas, choices of prior, empirical Bayesian methods, hierarchal Bayesian methods, statistical computation, Bayesian estimation, model selection, predictive analysis, applications, Bayesian software.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 3500 or STAT 4510 or STAT 7510 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
courses.description: (same as MATH 7315). Introduction to theory of probability and statistics using concepts and methods of calculus.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 or instructor's consent. No credit MATH 7315

courses.name: Introduction to Probability Theory
courses.description: (same as MATH 7320). Probability spaces; random variables and their distributions; repeated trials; probability limit theorems.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 2300 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Inference
courses.description: (same as MATH 7520). Sampling; point estimation; sampling distribution; tests of hypotheses; regression and linear hypotheses.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4750 or STAT 7750 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Nonparametric Methods
courses.description: A first course in Non-parametric statistical methods based on ranks. Both theory and application are emphasized. Two-sample problems. K-sample problems. Tests for independence. Contingency tables. Goodness-of-fit tests.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Categorical Data Analysis
courses.description: Discrete distributions, frequency data, multinomial data, chi-square and likelihood ratio tests, logistic regression, log linear models, rates, relative risks, random effects, case studies.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Introduction to Stochastic Processes
courses.description: Study of random processes selected from: Markov chains, birth and death processes, random walks, Poisson processes, renewal theory, Brownian motion, Gaussian processes, white noise, spectral analysis, applications such as queuing theory, sequential tests.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4750 or STAT 7750 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Time Series Analysis
courses.description: A study of univariate and multivariate time series models and techniques for their analyses. Emphasis is on methodology rather than theory. Examples are drawn from a variety of areas including business, economics and soil science.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 7710 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Problems in Statistics for Majors - Masters
courses.description: Approved reading and study, independent investigations, and reports on approved topics.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent

courses.name: Master's Thesis Research in Statistics
courses.description: Graded on a S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: None Listed

courses.name: Special Topics in Statistics
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent

courses.name: Applied Statistical Models II
courses.description: Advanced applied linear models including mixed linear mixed models (fixed and random effects, variance components, correlated errors, split-plot designs, repeated measures, heterogeneous variance), generalized linear models (logistic and Poisson regression), nonlinear regression. No credit toward a graduate degree in statistics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4510 or STAT 7510 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Data Analysis I
courses.description: Applications of linear models including regression (simple and multiple, subset selection, regression diagnostics), analysis of variance (fixed, random and mixed effects, contrasts, multiple comparisons) and analysis of covariance; alternative nonparametric methods.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4710 or STAT 7710 or STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Data Analysis II
courses.description: Advanced applications including analysis of designs (e.g. repeated measures, hierarchical models, missing data), multivariate analysis (Hotelling's T2, MANOVA, discriminant analysis, principal components, factor analysis), nonlinear regression, generalized linear models, categorical data analysis.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 8310 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Data Analysis III
courses.description: An introduction to data analysis techniques associated with supervised and unsupervised statistical learning. Resampling methods, model selection, regularization, generalized additive models, trees, support vector machines, clustering, nonlinear dimension reduction.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 8320

courses.name: Statistical Consulting
courses.description: Participation in statistical consulting under faculty supervision. Formulation of statistical problems. Planning of surveys and experiments. Statistical computing. Data analysis. Interpretation of results in statistical practice.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 and STAT 8320 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Theory of Bioinformatics
courses.description: Study of statistical theory and methods underpinning bioinformatics.  Topics include statistical theory used in biotechnologies such as gene sequencing, gene alignments, microarrays, phylogentic trees, evolutionary models, proteomics and imaging.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760

courses.name: Bayesian Analysis I
courses.description: Bayes' theorem, subjective probability, non-informative priors, conjugate prior, asymptotic properties, model selection, computation, hierarchical models, hypothesis testing, inference, predication, applications.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 and MATH 4140 or MATH 7140 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Intermediate Mathematical Statistics I
courses.description: Sample spaces, probability and conditional probability, independence, random variables, expectation, distribution theory, sampling distributions, laws of large numbers and asymptotic theory, order statistics.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Intermediate Mathematical Statistics II
courses.description: Further development of estimation theory, including sufficiency, minimum variance principles and Bayesian estimation. Tests of hypotheses, including uniformly most powerful and likelihood ratio tests.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 8710 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Problems in Statistics for Majors - PhD
courses.description: Approved reading and study, independent investigations, and reports on approved topics.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent

courses.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Statistics
courses.description: Graded on a S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: None Listed

courses.name: Recent Developments in Statistics
courses.description: The content of the course which varies from semester to semester, will be the study of some statistical theories or methodologies which are currently under development, such as bootstrapping, missing data, non-parametric regression, statistical computing, etc.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 and instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Computation and Simulation
courses.description: Random number generation, acceptance/rejection methods; Monte Carlo; Laplace approximation; the EM algorithm; importance sampling; Markov chain Monte Carlo; Metropolis-Hasting algorithm; Gibbs sampling, marginal likelihood.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Theory of Linear Models
courses.description: Theory of multiple regression and analysis of variance including matrix representation of linear models, estimation, testing hypotheses, model building, contrasts, multiple comparisons and fixed and random effects.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 and MATH 4140 or MATH 7140, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Linear Models
courses.description: Advanced topics in the theory and application of linear models. Specific content varies with instructor.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 9310 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Multivariate Analysis
courses.description: Distribution of sample correlation coefficients. Derivation of generalized T-squared and Wishart distributions. Distribution of certain characteristic roots, vectors. Test of hypotheses about covariance matrices and mean vectors. Discriminant analysis.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 and MATH 4140 or MATH 7140 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Survival Analysis
courses.description: Statistical failure models, Kaplan-Meier estimator, Log-rank test, Cox's regression model, Multivariate failure time date analysis, Counting process approaches.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Theory of Nonparametric Statistics
courses.description: Estimation, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, etc., when functional form of the population distribution is unknown.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Data Mining and Machine Learning Methods
courses.description: Approaches to estimating unspecified relationships and findings unexpected patterns in high dimensional data.  Computationally intensive methods including splines, classifications, tree-based and bagging methods, support vector machines.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4110 or STAT 7110, STAT 4760 or STAT 7760 and STAT 8320 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Bayesian Analysis II
courses.description: Likelihood principle, decision theory, asymptotic properties, advanced topics in Bayesian analysis at the instructor's discretion.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 8640 and STAT 9710 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Mathematical Statistics I
courses.description: Advanced study of mathematical statistics appropriate for PhD students in statistics. Elements of probability theory, principles of data reduction, point and interval estimation, methods of finding estimators and their properties, hypothesis testing, methods of finding test functions and their properties. Decision theoretic, classical and Bayesian perspectives.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 8720 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Mathematical Statistics II
courses.description: Continuation of STAT 9710. Topics include distribution theory and convergence, laws of large numbers, central limit theorems, efficiency, large sample theory, and elements of advanced probability.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 9710 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Probability
courses.description: (same as MATH 8480). Measure theoretic probability theory. Characteristic functions; conditional probability and expectation; sums of independent random variables including strong law of large numbers and central limit problem.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 4750 STAT 7750 or MATH 4700 or MATH 7700 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Stochastic Processes
courses.description: (same as MATH 8680). Markov processes, martingales, orthogonal sequences, processes with independent and orthogonal increments, stationarity, linear prediction.
courses.prerequisites: STAT 9810 or instructor's consent
